results.title: The Nature of life: the living cell
results.brief_description: Photomicrography investigates single-celled and multi-celled organisms - how they produce or absorb food, convert food to energy, respond to their environments, and reproduce. Simple experiments seen through a standard microscope demonstrate the functions of cell structures; an electron microscope reveals smaller cell structures.
results.title_for_label: The Nature of life: the living cell
results.description: Photomicrography investigates single-celled and multi-celled organisms - how they produce or absorb food, convert food to energy, respond to their environments, and reproduce. Simple experiments seen through a standard microscope demonstrate the functions of cell structures; an electron microscope reveals smaller cell structures.

results.title: The Nature of life: respiration in animals
results.brief_description: Explores the similarities of air-breathing and water-breathing animals, developing this concept through the animal kingdom to man himself. Demonstrations show the vital relationships between the animal’s size and the complexity of its respiratory system - between respiration, blood circulation and feeding.
results.title_for_label: The Nature of life: respiration in animals
results.description: Explores the similarities of air-breathing and water-breathing animals, developing this concept through the animal kingdom to man himself. results.title: The Nature of heat
results.brief_description: Explains heat as the energy of molecular motion. Experiments are used to demonstrate that heat is transferred by conduction, convection and radiation. Shows the effectiveness of various types of material in the transfer of heat.
results.description: Explains heat as the energy of molecular motion. Experiments are used to demonstrate that heat is transferred by conduction, convection and radiation. Shows the effectiveness of various types of material in the transfer of heat.

results.title: The Nature of healing
results.creator_credit: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
results.brief_description: This 6 part series draws upon the combined knowledge of Eastern and Western medicine, and reveals techniques and therapies to achieve true health and harmony. It will change the way life and health is perceived.

results.title: The Nature of culture
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Culture is the set of beliefs and practices which enable us to adapt to our circumstances, but it is more than a survival tool as it circumscribes, filters and gives value to reality. Patterns of culture are passed on from one generation to another through symbols, example and ceremony, but as the world shrinks in size and communication with other cultures becomes commonplace, some cultures are in danger of disappearing, destroyed by other more dominant cultures. Their preservation or careful assimilation is of vital importance. Narrated by David Carradine

results.title: The Nature of colour: parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
Shows the nature of white light by experiments involving the dispersion and re-combination of colours of the spectrum. Illustrates the nature of colour by demonstrations showing the reflection, transmission and absorption of colour.

results.title: The Nature of anthropology
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Every man and woman has a story to tell which is finally the story of us all. The basic tenet of modern anthropology is that people are fundamentally alike but different and that all cultures are valid approaches to answering the question of who and what we are. Unfortunately this belief has not always been held, resulting in genocide, as in the case of the Tasmanian Aborigines. Of the two major strands of anthropology - physical and cultural, this series is primarily concerned with cultural anthropology. Narrated by David Carradine.

Of the two major strands of anthropology - physical and cultural, this series is primarily concerned with cultural anthropology. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: The Nature and development of affection
results.brief_description: An experiment with chimpanzees. One animal is placed in a compartment with a wired cage source of milk, a “wire mother”, another is placed with a similar wire source of milk but this is covered with a furry material and is known as the “cloth mother”. Experiments contrast the social behaviour and the amount of affection which grows with each animal and “mother”. Towards the end a human baby is shown to be attracted to a cloth mother. The University of Wisonsin Department of Psychology, Primate Laboratory with Dr. Harry F. Harlow.

results.title: The Nature & nurture of development:Pt I
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Shows how development always occurs in context and that time and place are important in child development, together with biology. This program examines what has been learnt from recent research and considers moral development and the effects of environment in the nature/nurture controversy.

results.title: The Nature & nurture of development: Pt II
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Shows how development always occurs in context and that time and place are important in child development, together with biology. This program considers childhood rites of passage and acculturisation. It also presents a review of topics such as mental agility, physical growth, language and personality development.
